messages: dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (02:47): Question: Using Qt 4.2 with MinGW. Can I link a Qt Application directly to a .dll file or do I need to create some other file to link?
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (02:48): You should be able to, yeah.
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (02:48): ahigerd: I get a LD segmentation fault.
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (02:48): Odd.
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (02:48): Sure the library is valid?
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (02:49): ahigerd: Should the dll .h be aded to HEADERS or simply using it as #include in the code will work?
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (02:49): As #include is sufficient; after all, QtCore4.dll is a standard dll file
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (02:49): And you don't HEADERS += qapplication.h
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (02:49): indeed
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (02:49): How can I verify the validity of the .dll file?
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (02:49): I've linked to libcrypt.so on Linux before; I'm not sure why it wouldn't work on Windows.
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (02:50): Got anything else linking to it?

dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (02:51): ahigerd: Basically, I am cross-compiling with MinGW on Ubuntu with Qt 4.2. I succeeded in creating the .dll file, but when I try to compile the application linking to it, i got this strange LD segmentation fault.

dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (02:52): ahigerd: So I looked on the Qt Forum about it. I found a topic (http://www.qtforum.org/article/17176/Link-with-a-external-DLL.html) stipulating I need a .a file instead of .dll file.
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (02:52): ahigerd: What is a .a file?
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (02:52): Static library
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (02:52): That is not what I want.
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (02:52): MinGW static library, at that
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (02:53): Maybe it's not actually a static library
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (02:54): ahigerd: Now, just to be certain, how would you write in the .pro file that you want to link to a .dll ?
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (02:55): ahigerd: I use:     LIBS += -L"../../../some/path" -lmylib
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (02:55): Yes.
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (02:55): So that is the way it should be.
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (02:56): Is there a way to verify that my .dll file is not corrupted or something?
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (02:56): Now, there are some other conflicts I've seen with DLL files (i.e. MySQL)
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (02:56): Um... like I said, got something else that can link to it? Maybe something built with MSVC?
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (02:57): Dynamically link you mean?
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (02:58): Yeah
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (02:58): I could try that.
66d35671db185f8b0fa272c162b661d5 (02:59): http://www.canon-europe.com/Support/Software/Linux/registration.asp")
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (03:00): Should I try explicit or implicit linking?
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (03:00): ?
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (03:01): Not familiar with the difference

dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (03:01): ahigerd: Implicit linking is what I am using right now. That is: using the objects contained in the library as if it was compiled along the application. Explicit would be to use QLibrary objects.
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (03:05): ahigerd: So, do you use QLibrary objects?
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (03:05): Yeah
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (03:06): But I'm on Linux, and it seems to work flawlessly with standard .so files
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (03:06): Indeed it works fine.
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (03:06): I've done both forms of linking -- I linked with libcrypt implicitly and my own plugins explicitly. (That sounds backwards...)
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (03:07): But cross-compiling for windows is making me seasick.
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (03:07): And as far as I know, implicit linking of Qt-built DLLs under Windows works fine.
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (03:07): As long as they're built the same way.
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (03:08): I'm at the point of considering building it natively on Windows.
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (03:08): I'd recommend it.
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (03:08): Even if it's just in a VM
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (03:09): Exactly what I was thinking.
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (03:09): Last I knew WINE doesn't run under Cygwin, but I've never checked virtualizing the other direction.
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (03:09): I think it's worth a try.
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (03:09): Indeed.
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (03:09): I'm on it.
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (03:09): Thanks for you help!
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (03:09): Can't see why it WOULDN'T work if you provide it with the real Windows DLLs.
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (03:10): For reference, not for execution
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (03:10): yeah, well
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (03:10): hehe
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (03:10): I'm not a Windows fan so it'll have to do for now.
cdf4ad80dc66a41f951abab3fde0d774 (03:10): It might work without since WINE does a pretty good job of interpreting...
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (03:11): Do you think wine can actually install Qt?
dc54cbff49eb46541e5e869bbb30c032 (03:11): with MinGW?
145fa9389c89c71966fe2a9787b734d7 (03:17): When I run my kde4 program it segfaults very quickly when making a kapplication
145fa9389c89c71966fe2a9787b734d7 (03:17): it appears to be segfaulting inside of QImage
145fa9389c89c71966fe2a9787b734d7 (03:17): http://paste.ubuntu-nl.org/23167
7f1f8018ee6238f734df7d2512166a52 (03:17): fbolduc: Possibly. :P
145fa9389c89c71966fe2a9787b734d7 (03:17): i recently changed my video card to a much older version
145fa9389c89c71966fe2a9787b734d7 (03:17): i wonder if that's the cause
145fa9389c89c71966fe2a9787b734d7 (03:18): does qt compile differently depending on the video card or x extensions or something?
